{"step_by_step_thinking": "The active management of the third stage of labour is a method used to prevent postpartum hemorrhage. It includes the administration of a uterotonic drug, usually oxytocin, immediately after the delivery of the baby, controlled cord traction to deliver the placenta, and early clamping and cutting of the umbilical cord. However, the direct injection of oxytocin after delivery of the anterior shoulder is not part of this management. It is usually given after the delivery of the baby, not after the delivery of the anterior shoulder.", "answer_choice": "A"}
